title: What's News --  Business & Finance
text:
Companies world-wide have embarked on an unprecedented deal spree this year, with the wave of activity yielding a windfall in advisory fees for banks.

---

Intel plans to build new chip-making facilities in Europe valued at up to $95 billion, responding to a cross-border race to add manufacturing capacity.

---

Deutsche Telekom is speeding up its efforts to retake a majority stake in T-Mobile US through a complex transaction with SoftBank.

---

Elliott Management has a more than $1 billion stake in Citrix and wants the company to take action to boost its stock price.

---

BlackRock raised roughly $1 billion for the first mutual fund solely run by a foreign firm that is allowed to sell to Chinese individuals.

---

Toyota said it would spend $9 billion over the next decade to build factories for electric-car batteries.

---

Ford wooed executive Doug Field away from Apple to bolster its own efforts to better integrate software in automobiles.

---

The S&P 500 and Dow fell 0.3% and 0.8%, respectively, while the Nasdaq rose 0.1% to a record.

---

State Street agreed to buy Brown Brothers Harriman's investor-services unit for $3.5 billion.

---

Chinese authorities dropped the case against a former Alibaba manager accused of sexually assaulting a co-worker.
